hints_html:
There are two key questions we need to think about. Firstly, what would be a good function to use to approximate \((2.001)^{4}\)? Secondly, what would be a good value to use as a linear approximation?

Try using the function \(f(x) = x^{4}\) and the linear approximation around the point \(a=2\).

The linear approximation of \(f\) at x = a is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a)\end{aligned}\]

around the point $a=2$.
hints_raw:
There are two key questions we need to think about. Firstly, what would be a good function to use to approximate <math> (2.001)^{4} </math>? Secondly, what would be a good value to use as a linear approximation?
Try using the function <math> f(x) = x^{4}</math> and the linear approximation around the point <math> a=2</math>.
The linear approximation of &fnof; at ''x = a'' is given by

:<math> \displaystyle
L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a)
</math>
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
Let \(f(x) = x^{4}\), so \(f'(x) = 4x^{3}\). The linear approximation of \(f(x)\) at 2 is given by

\[\begin{aligned} L(x) &= f(2) + f'(2)(x-2) \\ &= 2^{4} + 4\cdot2^{3}(x-2)\\ &= 16 + 32(x-2)\end{aligned}\]

Thus, \((2.001)^{4} \approx L(2.001) = 16 + 32 \cdot(2.001-2) = 16 + \tfrac{32}{1000} = \tfrac{16032}{1000}\)
sols_latex:
Let $f(x) = x^{4}$, so $f'(x) = 4x^{3}$. The linear approximation of
$f(x)$ at 2 is given by

\begin{align*}
L(x) &= f(2) + f'(2)(x-2) \\
&= 2^{4} + 4\cdot2^{3}(x-2)\\
&= 16 + 32(x-2)
\end{align*}

Thus,
$(2.001)^{4} \approx L(2.001) = 16 + 32 \cdot(2.001-2) = 16 + \tfrac{32}{1000} = \tfrac{16032}{1000}$
sols_raw:
Let <math> f(x) = x^{4}</math>, so <math>f'(x) = 4x^{3} </math>. The linear approximation of <math> f(x)</math> at 2 is given by

<math> 
\begin{align}
L(x) &= f(2) + f'(2)(x-2) \\
&= 2^{4} + 4\cdot2^{3}(x-2)\\
&= 16 + 32(x-2)
\end{align}
</math>

Thus, <math> (2.001)^{4} \approx L(2.001) = 16 + 32 \cdot(2.001-2) = 16 + \tfrac{32}{1000} = \tfrac{16032}{1000}</math>
statement_html:
Short-Answer Questions. Questions 1-4 are short-answer questions. Put your answers in the boxes provided. Simplify your answers as much as possible, and show your work. Each question is worth 3 marks, but not all questions are of equal difficulty.

Use a linear approximation to estimate \((2.001)^{4}\). Write your answer in the form \(n/1000\), where n is an integer.
